review_title: Great environment for a seasoned startup professional
pros:
Affirm offers a very mature environment - not to be confused with staunchy or boring, but one that is fun for the right reasons (challenging, collaborative, and clean).

The team is incredibly smart, willing to challenge each other in the pursuit of doing things better (and more importantly for the right reasons).

The leadership team is honest and transparent, willing to answer tough questions in front of the whole company, available to offer support, keeps Affirm's values at the forefront of each decision and conversation.

The benefits are bonkers! Free quarterly books, daily lunches and dinners, stipends for everyday (and monthly) expenses, truly flexible vacation time, some of SF's best coffee options, and monthly company-wide outings/events that are actually fun :) You truly feel invested in as an employee at Affirm.
cons:
The company is growing at a rate that causes consistent change and communication challenges regularly. This isn't unique to Affirm, just to the time we're in as a company. If you can't handle consistent change, not the place for you.

Our mission runs deep within each team player (which I guess is a pro) but it's not an easy mission and our product is not simple at all. We're transforming an incredibly old industry that touches the personal lives of millions of people and has skeptics in every corner. We have to have hard conversations both internally and externally and it takes a long time to truly understand all of the ins and outs of our business model. Any position you take with Affirm will offer unexpected challenges, which may sound cliche but is truer than most companies I've supported. This isn't so much a con as a be aware that although we've worked hard to make Affirm look simple to consumers, the secret sauce is not.

Sometimes it feels like there are too many cooks in the kitchen for simple decisions. Because of the nature of our product, each project and decision can involve 2 - 6 different teams and multiple people per team. You must be able to navigate internal dynamics, needs, wants, personalities, and do so patiently. This can certainly be frustrating but it's a part of the culture and is something we're optimizing on a regular basis.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep the transparency alive. Keep investing in your employees. Be aware of the operational communication breakdowns and provide guidance to managers and team members on ways to improve.

pros:
- Outstanding peers: some of the smartest and most capable people I've had the pleasure to work with

- Positive consumer impact: the strong NPS of Affirm borrowers and powerful stories of how Affirm helped people in times of need are genuinely inspiring

- Solid leadership: the maturity and experience of the executive team really shows up in the confidence and candor with which they lead

- Interesting problems: Affirm's business and tech stack are complex and deep, which brings a new challenge every day

- Strong compensation, benefits, and perks
cons:
- Demanding work environment: Affirm isn't for slouches! The tremendous growth and success of the company also means that there is always more to do than time to do it. Managers are very supportive of ensuring you get the time you need to recover, but finding work/life balance requires the ability to set strict personal limits and stick with them.

- Complexity: Affirm's business and technology are difficult to fully understand, even for people who have worked at the company for a while. This can make it hard to get things done, since even seemingly small changes often have knock-on effects in other areas.

- Limited structured career path: As is true of other small-to-midsize companies I've worked at, Affirm doesn't have the same well-defined career trajectory that you'd find at a larger company like Google or Facebook. Especially for younger employees, this can feel scary or frustrating. The upside is that you get a ton of autonomy, responsibility, and rapid career growth if you can chart your own path. The downside is limited support to help you do so.
advice_to_mgmt:
You're doing much more right than wrong. For the most part, stick with what you're doing: attracting excellent talent, inspiring them with a big, bold vision, and setting clear priorities so people know where to focus. Also top marks for the level of transparency the leadership provides into the company financial, strategy, and decision-making.

Some opportunities to improve:
- People development could definitely be beefed up, especially for new middle managers stepping into the role for the first time.
- The medium term vision for Affirm is crystal clear, but we could have a sharper articulation of the big, giant 10 year vision.

pros: Affirm at it's core is a great product and I loved being able to sell a product that I believed in.

My whole team got laid off due to poor planning and vision for the sales team. They laid my team off because of not hitting their quota, and they did so in phases and I was one of the last to go because I was the only person on my team who had never missed quota.

I had almost a whole month of "limbo". I didn't have a job anymore so my time was spent trying to find a job internally. My experience interviewing with different teams was honestly terrible. I could tell that everyone I interviewed with had already made their mind up before they had even spoken to me. So every conversation was very awkward, unhelpful and eventually they just became humiliating.

They eventually laid me off, and out of the 50+ people in my department, only a couple people reached out to me after I had gotten let go to see how I was feeling. Mind you, I thought all of these people were not just my coworkers, but friends.

The hardest thing about all of this is that Affirm preaches transparency and inclusion, yet I couldn't have gotten a treatment that was more opposite. I'm tired of tech companies lying through their teeth about values and not actually living them out. Their version of inclusion centers around blowing money on lavish treats after work, fancy team dinners and "cool" parties.

And maybe you're reading this and thinking, "This girls sounds bitter!"... You're darn right I am. I have had wonderful experiences in the tech industry, some of my best friends are former coworkers and I've been promoted due to killing quota. So I know that how I was treated at Affirm is not a reflection of the stellar work I gave to them.
advice_to_mgmt: Dont' string someone along and play with their life.

review_title: Okay place to be, culture is bad, reviews are kind of borked
pros:
* Good growth. If the economy stays like this - affirm is in the green.
* Great compensation. They pay a lot. Benefits are great.
* Extremely desperate to hire talent - you'll get a great paycheck if you're good.
* Decent product - the product team is improving with new better product leadership
cons:
* Lots of inflated titles. About all the Staff titled are a joke. They have inflated titles with very poor understanding of how things are to be done and how to scale. They only have these titles due to legacy context, not due to expertise.
* Diversity is lacking. I'm not talking about race or sex, it's just that all the people are the same - workaholics, hard to communicate with, snooty top 10 college grads. There was once a hiring meeting when 5 universities were on the screen and people were asked to raise hands if they were from those universities. About 60% people raised their hands and then clapped and nodded satisfyingly.
* Will not survive a recession at this stage - they raised more capital so maybe it's fine now. Remember, it's a payday loan company with cascading effects with how the loans are structured and managed - same as the 2007 subprime mortgage crisis. The company will run out of money very fast if a small portion of the customers default.
* Management is poor. None of the managers know how to empower their employees and make them successful. People get fired for stupid reasons or disagreeing.
* This is not one of those companies where team spirit and camaraderie are a thing.
* I think the rest of the reviews are from over the top new grads. The real story is not so rosy(or in this case - green).
advice_to_mgmt:
Teach the managers how to manage and not play favorites. Or get real managers.
Empowering people is not about posh media slogans or awareness campaigns that makes us look good on the outside. It's not about making values and cool logos of them. It's not about running random training exercises to train managers. The problems are too wide and disparate for a one size fits all approach.

You need to identify employees who are struggling, need direction and help them and help their managers help them. Manage the toxic people even if they are great performers.

Top level management is good - but mid level is horridly lacking.

There are times that I heard more junior employees being hesitant to reach out to you and chat - please continue to host more events where employees can get to know you and the company's vision / strategy. pros:
Growth and the opportunities that creates are the biggest pro of working at Affirm. Since I have joined in the last few months, huge wins have been made on the business development and sales sides that suggest this company has what it takes to reach escape velocity. As a software engineer, this makes it easy to understand what we need to build and how my contributions will move the business forward.

As important as partnerships are at this company, Affirm remains engineering focused, likely because of our founder. The benefits package, which feels generous for a startup of this size and profitability, caters toward building knowledge and excellence in all areas of life.

Recruiting is top notch, and I was surprised how well the company hires versus both the big box tech companies and other hot startups. Having only worked at companies with similar levels of talent, I was happy to not have to compromise here.
cons:
As with most fast moving startups, there is some technical debt. Also, the fast pace of the business means there is less time than I would like to explore new technologies for use at the company and for personal growth.

Additionally, while many startups win by making simplifying assumptions and avoiding regulation, we are a fintech company, and thus make it our competitive edge to deal with all the complexity that finance and regulation create. At times the nuance created by this can be frustrating.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep pushing. Greatness remains in sight! Also, I appreciate how we have a no nonsense culture compared to a bunch of other unicorns that have been in the press lately.

Please don't be fooled by all of the positive reviews. It's almost funny since everyone I worked with when I was there has since quit or is trying to leave. They are bleeding engineers like crazy and the sales/success teams are some of the most dysfunctional I've ever witnessed. Multiple people started and then left to go back to their old companies a month or two in once they experienced the culture at Affirm.

The culture at Affirm is very negative. Managers don't seem to care about their employees or about fostering a positive atmosphere. There is no such thing as work life balance. Most management has never managed before and it's painfully obvious. Do yourself a favor and pass up this "hot" company for somewhere that is an enjoyable place to work!

pros: Many of the teams are very much in sync and rally behind the mission. Makes it incredibly motivating to come into work each day, and the work itself becomes much more efficient. Benefits and perks aren't anything to complain about either.
cons: Very few. Things are changing a lot and you may have to wear many different hats. But that's a growing start up for you! Not much of a con though in my opinion.
advice_to_mgmt: Management does a fairly good job of being transparent with company decisions and changes. Good to have everyone on the same page as soon as possible.

review_title: Okay but not as great as it seems
pros: Really worthwhile mission, a lot of smart and good people, and working with Max Levchin has its benefits for sure.
cons: It's the blind leading the blind. There is a ton of inexperience in leadership and management roles. People with chops and experience leave out of frustration, and the inexperienced remain to move things forward. The "happy" people really just don't know any better/different. I would be surprised if Affirm ever becomes more than a company with potential.
advice_to_mgmt: Put real experience on the exec team and in leadership roles. Smarts only go so far, and in many cases, experience is king. Morale is way lower than you realize. And a lot of that is because you have kids running things. They have no idea how to manage nor lead.

review_title: A great company with a challenging culture and org structure
pros:
Great perks - ex, free lunch and dinner, free snacks and drinks, product testing stipend, cell phone reimbursement,
Great mission of providing financing to under-served portions of the population
Great work life balance - if you want to work just 8 hours a day, you can set those boundaries and people will respect them.
cons:
Lots and lots of interoffice politics - an executive team (with some people that are clearly on their way out) with limited strategic direction combined with tons of young people in a loosely defined org structure leads to a lot of politics.
Engineering focused - Affirm is a financial company, but has a huge emphasis from the top on engineering and sometimes makes the rest of the employees feel like second class citizens.
The downside to the above pro of great work-life balance is that there are a small portion of the Company that ends up doing an out-sized portion of the work with little to no recognition.
advice_to_mgmt: Determine and execute on a strategic direction - tons of hard work is being wasted since objectives and goals are loosely defined and always changed last minute.

pros:
-Mission driven company - if you and believe in what we are building (honest, transparent, and consumer friendly financial products) and are passionate about FinTech, then this is truly the place to be. We impact lives on a daily basis.

-The Executive Leadership team is made up of some of the best Silicon Valley has to offer. The access to Senior Leadership and ability to engage in open dialogue is quite unique.

- Incredibly smart and driven people. You will learn something new every day and be challenged to perform at the highest level. A collaborative work environment where egos are left at the door.
cons:
-Typical growing pains of any rapidly growing startup (never a dull moment!)

-Heavily regulated industry can be frustrating for delivering new products quickly
advice_to_mgmt: Honesty/transparency from senior leadership is extremely encouraging and motivating! Take calculated risks and speed up execution!

review_title: Best people I have ever worked with
pros:
- Ambitious mission, with tons of opportunities to grow
- Truly smart and passionate people - I am inspired by my colleagues on daily basis
- Open and transparent culture - Everyone's ideas and feedback are welcome and valued
- Strong executive team - if this team can not make it happen, I can't think of any other can
- Great benefits package
cons:
- Lack of prioritization in product team
- Pace is a bit slow in terms of rolling out new products
- A lot of regulations in finance, which makes it impossible to "move fast and break things" - might be annoying to some people
- Never have enough people to get things done
advice_to_mgmt: Love the transparency, keep it up! Narrow down the focus and accelerate the execution!

pros:
- Sincerely mission-driven company with a goal of transforming financial services
- Enormous opportunity to build a meaningful product
- Insanely smart colleagues -- learn something new every day
- Strong values, people-centric
- Committed to open & transparent dialogue
- Above-market benefits package
cons:
- Fair number of first time managers
- Diversity isn't great, but honestly working to improve

pros: Strong internal alignment, experienced and thoughtful leadership, established company values and longterm planning, delightful and smart people, good product market fit. Internal support for balance and flexibility on schedule. In general, a very good working environment and great people. Opportunities to grow a career here
cons: Like any start-up, there can be change and some heavy lifting on projects, but those can also be good things :)

pros:
Complex business problems to solve
Ambitious mission
High bar in terms of hiring
Flexibility to fail and immense amount of responsibility
No shortage of valuable work to go around
cons: Startup growing pains, limited on pace of growth, not radical enough
advice_to_mgmt: Take more risks more often

pros: Affirm still has the startup feel despite rapid growth. Benefits are outstanding. People are smart and fully engaged and management seems to be on track.
cons: All startups have growing pains, Affirm is no exception. Its chaotic at times and thats not for everyone.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep up the good work

pros:
- Very intelligent people
- Mission-driven
- High growth
- Plenty of opportunities for personal growth
cons:
- People can be arrogant
- There is a lack of prioritization
- People management needs to improve greatly
advice_to_mgmt: Narrow your focus and prioritize people management.

pros:
- hot startup in FinTech
- growing fast
- experienced founder
- great perks
- easy to stand behind the product
- great values
cons: - typical A-player competitive environment

review_title: One of the smartest moves I made in my career
pros:
Affirm really values its employees. There is a strong emphasis on workplace success and happiness. They really want to make sure they are providing the best environment for their employees to grow and excel in their roles.

The executive team is pretty hard to ignore too. A lot of great leadership with the skills to make a company successful.

We have great company events which really allow employees to get to know each other outside of the day to day working environment (white water rafting, happy hours, offsites, ski trip, etc.). Really great to be apart of a company that values this.
cons: I joined the company when they were well over 100 people, doesn't seem like a lot but it does get more challenging to get to know people and be more hands on with projects. However, they do emphasize on making sure employees are apart of projects they are passionate about.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep doing what you are doing.

pros: Leadership knows their stuff and do a great job coordinating teams. Extremely high bar for hiring. Exciting product that makes a real impact in people's lives outside of the valley. No end to the amount of interesting problems that need solving, regardless of what function of the business you're in.
cons: The high bar for hiring means we often don't grow teams as fast as we'd like. The business is so mature and complex at this point, and so many different improvements are happening in parallel, that it's no longer something you can fully wrap your head around if you're not an exec; you have to trust your peers are doing their piece of the puzzle in cross-functional departments (finance, engineering, operations, etc).
advice_to_mgmt: Invest even more in new product development to help with recruiting sell and making good on the mission

pros: The people in this company bring their A game Every. Single. Day. Their commitment to Affirm's mission is both incredibly inspiring and contagious. What surprised me the most is how welcoming and eager everyone is to share their expertise - zero ego. You are encouraged to be curious and to find ways to learn something new. The fintech space isn't for everyone, but if it's your thing, Affirm needs to be on your radar.
cons: Startup growing pains, but we are in the process of moving buildings which will eliminate the daily battle for conference rooms.
advice_to_mgmt: Continue to be transparent with your teams ; It will motivate them to give you their best.

pros:
Amazing team.
Exciting technology.
Very talented engineers.
Honest senior management.
Transparency within the company.
cons: Office space is getting a bit cramped. Growth pains. Moving to a new office is going to help.

review_title: Clear Aspirational Vision and the Talent to Execute
pros: Amazingly smart, hard-working, and friendly group of people that have a very clear directive from the exec team about the goal that we are moving towards but freedom to figure out the best path to get there. The perks and benefits are great, but it's the mission, quality of the team, and the momentum that we're starting to build which keep a lot of us excited to put in the long intense hours that our roles sometimes demand.
cons: As with any quickly growing company, we need to do a better job of making sure that mid-level managers are provided the support and resources they need to be effective leaders for their teams. That has not necessarily been a priority in the past but there is now a concerted effort to improve in this area.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep pushing us on expanding the vision but make sure we remain diligent about prioritizing our areas of focus at any given point in time.

pros:
Affirm has been a very rewarding place to work thus far. The team is by far the smartest, most talented team I've ever worked with, and I learn something new every day. Moreover, I was pleasantly surprised with the level of humility everyone has here.

There's an energy here that I picked up on during my interviews with Affirm; I think it stems from a drive to change the financial sector for the better, a dedication to quality, and a determination to succeed. It made me want to be part of what the team, and I am very glad I joined.
cons: Limited conference rooms. I know this will be fixed when we move to the new office, but having 1:1s can be tricky to do at communal tables. It inhibits the ability to address sensitive subjects openly. Hoping we will have enough conference rooms in the new office.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep up the transparency in all-hands meetings! Everyone here really values and appreciates it, so I hope we don't lose this open line of communication with execs and Max as we grow.

pros: Extremely smart people! Very collaborative environment, with a great culture, trying to solve hard problems.
cons: Some Start up growing pains
advice_to_mgmt: Keep up the sense of urgency!

pros: Inspiring company. Inspired people. Room to grow your career and build an amazing business.
cons: Still figuring out how to scale, but that's natural at a company of this stage.

pros: Very smart, ethical, thoughtful people who are among the most mission-driven I've ever encountered in my career. A company that is able to focus and execute on the here-and-now priorities necessary to achieve a wildly ambitious goal.
cons: Can always afford to move faster and more efficiently. Typical "startup-turning-grownup" pains around structure, career paths, talent underutilization.
advice_to_mgmt: The best talent have a mix of character, industry knowledge (retail, credit, finserv), and comparable-stage experience. Don't always look at the obvious places...they tend to not be able to keep up.

pros: Very intelligent people who are eager to help undergrads and new grads learn and grow. It's a rapidly growing company with much to achieve so everyone is given impactful work.
cons: Because it is a rapidly growing company, things can get lost in the shuffle

pros:
The benefits here are amazing - full health, lunch and dinner every day, Audible membership, gym, books every quarter, phone, etc.

I had high hopes for working at Affirm before I joined but I didn't know it would be this amazing. The people are geniuses, the work is incredibly fulfilling, our mission isn't just aspirational but we're already making a huge difference in peoples' lives.

Working for a company with experienced, and successful, founders and execs makes an enormous difference for the size of company we are now AND for the company we're building towards.

There is a proactive approach to the success of the company that lends itself well to the folks we attract for the team.

I've personally loved hearing more about our long term plans and the possibly impossible goal of re-inventing financial services.
cons: We don't do a great job of talking about the broader mission. Also, we need more conference rooms :)

pros: Affirm is a mission-driven company that genuinely wants to improve the lives of people through honest, transparent financial products. The company has a highly experienced leadership team that includes co-founder and CEO Max Levchin. They are mature hands but also passionate about what the company's trying to do. Affirm has attracted smart people who care deeply about the mission and want to do right by both its customers and colleagues within the company.
cons: Affirm is experiencing some of the challenges that are common to rapidly growing startups such as communicating at scale and making sure the culture evolves yet stays true to the core values of the company. That said, I've been impressed by the desire of the company to have honest, and at times difficult, conversations about how we could do better and to solicit direct feedback, both good and bad, from the everyone.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep tying everything we do to our long-term mission and continue to encourage everyone to have candid discussions about how we can improve.

pros:
I'm sure it seems fishy, a company with a solid 5-star review. It's all true. From the great perks and benefits to the amazing and brilliant people I work with, Affirm continues to be my best choice to date.

The culture here is great and inclusive. Everyone is friendly, willing to share their knowledge and expertise.

This is a hardworking group. Better be prepared to get here and start swimming.
cons:
Space is cramped because of the crazy growth, but even that doesn't bother me too much.

Lots of changes happening, which is expected.
advice_to_mgmt: Growing so quickly will have its pain points. Try hard to keep the culture positive, keep hiring the most brilliant and kind people and we'll all do great.

review_title: Great company culture and rewarding work
pros:
Great company culture, and awesome mission. I've had a positive experience here since my first interaction at Affirm. The recruiting and on boarding process was smooth and informative. It is an amazing environment in which you have the opportunity to work with some of the smartest people I've ever met, who are also yet humble.

The perks are also great, and lead to the employees being able to spend quality time together. We have catered lunch everyday, and fun company events once a month.

The whole community is very supportive and I've learned an incredible amount since I've started. We get the opportunity to attend lunch talks from other employees about what they are working on at Affirm.
cons:
Main issue is that there don't seem to be enough people to do the work. This generally leads to people having to take on more than their position should require. In general though this is somewhat positive because you have the freedom to work on a wide range of things, and with a greater impact.

Not enough space. At our current office we are pushing it on space. I know we're working on it, but it does lead to me being distracted and unable to do my work sometimes.
advice_to_mgmt: Management is great at being transparent, keep it up!

pros: Affirm engineering is an exceptionally smart group of people, and working here provides for a very intellectual environment. Affirm is particularly great for people who would like to maintain an interest in the more theoretical and academic aspects of computer science and software design and architecture, while at the same time working towards significant social impact.
cons: If you're looking for a company with very solid infrastructure, developer tooling, and support, then Affirm may not be the place for you. Our entire stack is very much a work in progress and all software developers are encouraged to make contributions across the board.

pros:
- You get to work with industry experts, with specializations ranging from Finance, Business Development, Sales, Engineering and Data Science.
- Extremely quick iteration time, and very rewarding work (you get to help customers understand credit on a day to day basis)
- The leadership team is extremely competent and has a lot of experience founding and running fin tech companies.
- The challenges that arise from working with money are interesting to solve and have small to non-existent margins or error. As a result the work you deliver is of consistently high quality.
- The management is very open and vocal with employees about business decisions.
- Competitive pay and benefits
cons:
- Working for any startup has some volatility associated with it, as your performance is somewhat pegged to the market
- Dealing with fraudulent users/accounts.

pros:
Working at Affirm is incredible. There is no where else I want to work at this moment. I am learning every day and am constantly challenged. The team at Affirm is bright, curious, and creative. It's a high density of intelligent people in every role.

The culture at Affirm is centered around integrity. People here care about creating a better financial product and as a result are fairly outspoken. Best argument wins, no matter where it comes from as long as it aligns with the principles of the company, has the data to back it up, and is supported by the strongest logic.

Most importantly, the leaders here are refreshingly transparent about the status of the company. There are no questions left unanswered, and the exec team proactively works to explain potentially confusing issues in the company.
cons: Most people here are very technical. Our founders are previous CTO's at other companies.
advice_to_mgmt: Thanks for being so transparent with the team!

pros: Some of the smartest and most articulate people I have met. The company culture is exceptionally hardworking, however there is plenty of fun to be had as well. The leadership team is inspiring and dedicated to the company mission - this trickles down to the rest of the employees as well.
cons: Really no negatives to share. Plenty of work to be done, and everyone is up to the challenge.
advice_to_mgmt: The management team is very transparent and forthright. This is greatly appreciated as the company begins to scale rapidly.

pros: The vision is compelling and very serious with zero fluff. The management very experienced and highly skilled. The product team is highly motivated.
cons: Rent in SF is very expensive.

pros:
Affirm is innovating in a big space by issuing loans in real-time and providing top-notch loan servicing. The company is still small (~30 people in the tech organization). These aspects make being an engineer very challenging and rewarding--we are small enough that every contributor needs to learn how to do a lot, with many developers contributing to the full stack.

Each of us need to develop enough awareness of the lending industry and its regulatory components to maintain a compliant lending system. This leads to a serious engineering culture with a big emphasis on automated testing, as bugs in the financial space can have dire consequences.

Everybody on my team is extremely intelligent and great to work with and learn from.

Overall, Affirm is a great place to work as a developer, especially one who enjoys high stakes challenges and developing a large breadth of software engineering skills.
cons: The biggest detractions to working at Affirm relate to the biggest benefits; since the stakes of what we are doing are so high, at times, things are stressful and require us to be extremely focused on our work. In short bursts, work-life balance can be very tilted towards work, although there's nothing quite as satisfying as deploying a financial product that hasn't existed before. Also, the company still has an unlimited vacation policy, and it's understood that folks need a break after putting in tough hours for a sprint. While I've only once in 2.5 years at Affirm had a manager actively tell me to take a break, whenever I ask for some time off, it's never a problem. Work-life balance is achievable at Affirm, but it requires the employee to be proactive about taking care of herself.
advice_to_mgmt: You have very good people. Continue to give them independence to contribute creatively. Encourage them to take good care of themselves and stay emotionally healthy.

pros:
From the recruiting process, to onboarding, to interacting with employees throughout the organization, I've been nothing been impressed with Affirm.

The interview process was very fast and fluid, and my recruiter was highly responsive and communicative throughout, from phone screen to offer. The onboarding process was much shorter and more straightforward than what I've experienced in the past, possibly because it's the first startup I've experienced. One highlight of the onboarding process was that the COO took the time to meet with a small group of new hires to take our feedback on the process and answer any questions we had. Definitely shows the exec team is committed to improving processes. Max also took the time to welcome me, which was a nice touch.

In my admittedly time working here I've also been impressed with everyone I've met, no matter their role or level. Independent of role, everyone is highly intellectually curious, which makes for a very dynamic and challenging work environment. Complacency is non-existent as far as I can tell, and it's apparent how invested everyone is in the long-term goals of the company. Not to be overly hyperbolic, but put simply if the mission and vision resonates with you, then I highly recommend Affirm as a great place to work.
cons: Never enough people to do the work..pretty certain this is an issue every comparable company faces though. A ping-pong table would be nice.

pros: Phenomenal leadership, culture of excellence and transparency, and general camaraderie among teams and employees. Everyone here believes in the product and mission. We're all aware of impact we have on our company's performance each day.
cons: When you're trying to change the face of the financial services industry, you may have to eat at your desk.
advice_to_mgmt: Thank you for trusting us with our aspirational mission and vision.

pros: Smart, highly motivated, and team oriented group. Team is passionate about the product, but even more so about partners and customers.
cons: Growing so quickly we need to find a new office space soon; seating will be a little tight for a few months.

pros: Nature of the work, prospects, management
cons: Adapting to growth - but to be expected
advice_to_mgmt: None - doing a great job

pros:
The financial industry is a massive and highly competitive space, which makes for a great fast-paced environment. The problems you set out to solve are challenging and large scale. Everyone at Affirm is extremely motivated, collaborative and strives to build great products. The leadership team is one of the best out there and make themselves available to everyone. There is a great level of trust and transparency, and taking ownership is highly encouraged/supported.

All in all, it's a group of talent people who enjoy what they do and make for a great company culture. Best place I've worked.
cons: It's a startup so you'll definitely work hard, but if you love what you do (like the individuals working here) it's a non-issue.
advice_to_mgmt: Doing great. Keep up the level of transparency and trust as we grow.

pros: The people and the mission are the two primary things I love about Affirm. In terms of people, I am surrounded with people who are smart and care about their work. Having the opportunity to work with and learn from so many people that are so good at what they do is a dream come true. With regard to our long-term mission it is daunting and exciting. While we remain focused on our short-term goals, it is exciting to know the clear strategy for achieving our future aspirations as well. I am not so naive to think that path won't change, but having a clear "North Star" is important and adjusting the path is half the fun. Just a note on my rating of "Work/Life Balance"... We work hard because we care about what we are working on and we want it to be successful. Whether you are right out of school or have a family, people with both backgrounds have been very successful at Affirm.
cons: The financial industry is not for the faint of heart. Ex. Building a social network and you lose someone's photo upload it's not the end of the world. Building a financial system and you lose someones money simply can't happen. With this comes a level of responsibility and attention to detail that not everyone may find appealing. That said, I assure you that the challenges you will face and opportunities you have will greatly expand your career and refine your skills.
advice_to_mgmt: As we grow and need additional leaders either continue to grow them from within or find people as smart and experienced as you! That management team is one of the strongest aspects of the company and I have learned SO much from them.

pros: Employees are hardworking, engaged and friendly. Management values and rewards hard work. Feedback and better solutions are always encouraged.
cons: Affirm won't be the right fit for you if you do not thrive in a fast-paced and quickly changing environment.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep pushing us to improve our process and reach new goals!

pros: Working in fintech with some of the best! Strong engineering team that has a commitment to quality and rigor. World-class leadership team
cons: It's a startup so sometimes there is a lot of work to do and things to be ironed out. The team has a lot of experience and it runs much more smoothly than other startups where I've worked.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep on doing what you're doing.

pros:
- High-impact projects
- Lots of smart people around
- Fun to hang-out with people outside of work
cons:
- Changes happening often
- Not much else tbh

pros:
Great opportunity
Flexibility
No much work pressure
cons: I was happy working with company so nothing to write here
